awd_titl_txt: Mechanistic Chemistry of Reactive Sulfur Species
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics & Mechanisms B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Ming Xian of the Department of Chemistry at Washington State University plans to explore the chemical reactivity and properties of three important reactive sulfur species (hydrogen polysulfides, S-nitroso hydrogen sulfide, and selenopersulfides). These species play regulatory roles in biological systems; However, their mechanisms of action are not clear.  Through the studies of their reactivities and reaction mechanisms with other biologically relevant molecules, the investigators seek to determine how these sulfur species regulate biological systems.   The research will be carried out by graduate and undergraduate students, as part of their professional training for careers in STEM.  Efforts will be made to recruit students from underrepresented groups to participate in this project.

Sulfur-based reactive species have been known as critical redox regulators in biological systems. However, the functions of some species such as hydrogen polysulfides, S-nitroso hydrogen sulfide, and selenopersulfides are not well understood.  Studies of these molecules are challenging because of their highly reactive nature under physiological conditions.  In this project, ways to produce these molecules cleanly will be developed.  Studies of their reactivities and reaction mechanisms with other biologically relevant molecules will then become feasible and will be performed.  These studies will advance our knowledge of these reactive species and further our understanding of their roles in biological systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Reactive sulfur species are sulfur-containing molecules that play important regulatory roles in biological systems. Many of these molecules are highly reactive and unstable in nature, therefore, understanding their biological functions has been challenging. In this project, Dr. Ming Xian and his team at Brown University carried out experiments to investigate the fundamental chemistry and reactions of three reactive sulfur species: hydrogen polysulfides (H2Sn), S-nitroso hydrogen sulfide (HSNO), and selenopersulfides (RSeSH). They designed and prepared several series of precursors for these sulfur species. With these compounds, novel methods for the controllable generation of H2Sn, HSNO, and RSeSH were developed. For example, 1-thioglucose was used in conjugation with two enzymes (glucose oxidase and chloroperoxidase) to in situ generate H2Sn. This represents the first carbohydrate-based system for the delivery of reactive sulfur species. In addition, a photo-responsive template for the light-triggered release of H2Sn and HSNO was developed. Both ultraviolet (UV) light and sunlight can be used to promote the release of those sulfur species. With these methods in hand, some unique reactivities of these sulfur species were discovered. For example, we tested a series of electrophiles to trap reactive sulfur species and explored specific fluorescent sensors.  H2Sn were demonstrated to be stronger nucleophiles, reductants, as well as thiyl radical precursors than H2S and thiols. RSeSH were found to be the key intermediates in diselenide-catalyzed H2Sn formation from H2S. These results pave the ways to better understand the biological significance of these reactive sulfur species. Our studies also led to several published review articles that summarize the reactions and properties of reactive sulfur species. These are expected to be useful references for researchers in this field. Overall, this project has produced 15 publications in peer reviewed journals. Eight graduate students and seven undergraduate students worked on this project and received training in both chemistry and chemical biology. They carried out experiments to investigate reactive sulfur species and participated in writing scientific reports and manuscripts. The PI gave 14 presentations (including seminars at different universities and invited talks at international conferences) to disseminate the results generated from this project. The students also gave oral and poster presentations about this project at local, national, and international conferences.


Last Modified: 08/03/2024
Modified by: Ming Xian
